column18: Fees of $6000 to $10000 to publish after slow reviews and turnaround times by the journal are absurd. The system is broken yet we are often required or encouraged to publish in open access journals by NIH et al but we do not have the funds in our limited budget to cover this. The fees are not sustainable with the current level of support by NIH and non-profits. These fees may eat up as much as 10-20% of a small non profit grant. How are we supposed to cover our salaries, our lab salaries, pay for space and supplieds, and then also pay these absurd fees?
column19: Help is needed. Current university support and external funding is not keeping up with the cost of things and faculty are burning out. This is another small reason we are seeing less and less PhDs doing postdoctoral training.

column17: It is much easier for me to pay publishing fees than other researchers in my field
column19: Page charges and open access fees are being exploited by so-called elite journals because of their perceived status. Individuals are more than willing to pay $5-10K or more to publish in Nature and Cell title journals often because of careerism. Members of promotion and tenure committees or grant review panels are often so specialized that they cannot evaluate science outside of their narrow areas. So having the imprimatur of Cell or Nature in the journal title gives the allure of significance or importance. This is corrupting.

column18: I would love to have more university-level support for these open access publication charges.  On the other hand, some publishers charge quite a lot for open access publication and yet offer very little in the way of editorial support.  I think the charges from some such publishers, such as Public Library of Science, are quite excessive.
column19: I have heard some discussion about replacing the current publication model with the practice of simply posting articles online.  I think this is a terrible idea.  Despite various complaints out there, I think the peer reviewing process generally does a good job selecting which papers merit publication and leading to improvements in papers before they are published.  And effective editorial support (proofreading, typesetting, etc) can also have a significant positive impact on paper quality.

column17: It is about the same difficulty for me to pay publishing fees than other researchers in my field
column18: Open access journals cost money to operate, just like other journals do. For me, the question is where the money should come from. One might say that the costs should be borne by their institutional hosts (universities, professional associations or societies), but that begs the question: where do those institutions get their money?  Some have endowments; most rely on some combination of membership fees, subsidies or allocations from the state (i.e., appropriations from the public sector), and direct grants from philanthropies or public funders.  It's cost spreading, no matter how you cut it.  Should researchers be included or excluded from the relevant cost spreading mechanism?  If they're excluded, why?  If they're included, to what extent?  To my knowledge, there is no consistent reasoning behind answers to either question.  It's all ad hoc.

column18:
The system of publishing fees is inherently unfair. I guess it is to be expected in a capitalist society, but I am  in academia partly because when I entered I perceived it to be less susceptible to those economic forces. 

I am conflicted about my participation in open source publishing. Our article was originally submitted to [SUBSCRIPTION JOURNAL NAME]. We were referred to [OPEN ACCESS JOURNAL NAME] because they were just beginning the journal - that is why they waived the fee. Initial publications were promised a waived fee,  and so my  co-authors and I benefited from that timing. I just think it is inherently unfair that the public doesn't have open access to ALL published materials, especially when the opportunity to pay for publishing is not equally distributed among faculty. We need a better system! As you can see by my answers above, I object to the fees on principle, not because of the cost. Why should I benefit from paying a fee that others' can't afford? Why would I want this to be a reason why my work is used/cited by others? It should be read and used/cited on its merits, not some artifact of gamesmanship or privilege.
column19: Thank you for doing this survey. I hope my colleagues also express similar frustration with the current system.

column18: I really think these fees have gotten out of hand. Especially for junior researchers who may have little or no extramural funding, the fees present a dilemma. You have to publish to advance, but if you run out of money you won't be able to continue your research, and you won't advance. For the particular journal article that this survey referenced, the publisher offered to waive the fee if we submitted our work to that particular journal. This was the determining factor for me. If I hadn't had to choose between one journal that didn't charge a fee and a handful of others that would charge $3,000+ (!), I probably would have submitted to one of the other journals. But since I really felt like I needed to conserve resources, I opted for the journal that would waive the fee. Not a great system. I also really don't understand where these fees go/what they are funding. They seem exorbitant for, what exactly? Putting my document into a template, loading it on a website, and adding it to some databases?

It would be reasonable if investigators covered only costs related to editorial stipends, copy editing, and online hosting (assuming that publishers will provide these data transparently).

column18: I actually have no idea where others get funding to pay, but I know increasingly it is hard to find a journal that is not open access, and all have exorbitant fees. The fees feel really arbitrary.
column19: There's a huge need to change the business model of academic publishing. It is a real problem and an issue of equity. Journals need to make their money in other ways, or perhaps we need to establish/accept new ways of getting quality peer-reviewed material out to the world. I also think that science suffers under the current model--journals need to meet quotas to generate revenue, accept poorer science, and researchers are rewarded for publishing more articles--no matter the quality. Peer reviewers aren't compensated or compensated in ways that aren't super meaningful, so it's harder and harder to find qualified peer reviewers to accept the review. Science lags and poorer quality research is published. I have been/am an Associate Editor for 3 journals (1 open access, 2 not), and I see this happening all the time. It makes me angry, but I also have to play this game as a researcher.

column18: The proportion of grant money that has to be set aside for APCs feels ridiculous, and unfair when that funding comes from public tax dollars and then is just shuttled straight to wildly profitable publishers.  Also, publications in "good journals" are required to get funding in the first place, and this can place a strain on researchers who don't yet have funding, but need to publish.  Notably, subscription (non open access) journals often also have high fees for page charges.
column19: I do factor in the APC in my decision of where to submit papers.  Some open access journals I can submit to have no APC or have negotiated agreements with UTK (PLoS) and so I favor those when possible, but sometimes the most appropriate journals are more expensive.  Costs for similar impact factor journals have ranged for us from $1000-$5000, and it seems arbitrary why some are so much more expensive than others.  I used to budget $2500 per year for publications in my grant, but in my recent submission, I increased that to $10k, because that better matches reality, even though it seems unreasonable.  I have also recently realized that some non open access journals also charge $1000-$3000 APCs just as "page and color figure charges".  This realization has made me more likely to choose open access journals, so at least the money goes to help make the work available, rather than the "double charging" model of a subscription journal with a long embargo that also has a $2000 fee.

column18: The whole premise of fees for publishing is wrong-headed. We researchers pay to do the research. We pay to publish the research. We pay more to publish the research open access. And that is before you investigate equity concerns...

column18: I think it has become very clear to many researchers that Open Access Fees are yet one more barrier to equality. The notorious biases in grant funding against diverse individuals mean that only the richest, and thus, the whitest, male-est, most senior people are easily able to pay for open access publications. What this means is that the publications which are read by the general population are going to be from the least diverse people. This is sad. I pay for public access when I can, but do  not begrudge those who can't. Other solutions, particularly involving universities committing to paying open access fees or journals dropping those fees, seem important to investigate.
